posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: The “great game” between Britain and Russia
posts.com:
One of the UKs biggest fears was the Russian empire marching south, conquering places like Persia. Thus giving them both a warm water port all year around, and making british India much more vulnerable

But would the Russians have been able to consolidate any gains they make southwards? The warm water port sounds good... except it would be as far as possible away from the actual naval areas that needed defending in the west and eastern parts of Russia.

Also if they use it for trade, they’d need a massive amount of railroads all through Persia and up back towards the Russian cities. They had a hard enough time building the trans Siberian railway so I don’t know if they could even do this through all those Persian mountains

Finally. Would russia have even been in a position to invade India just because they’d border it? Russia had a ton of men and a massive army... but that’s all they had going for them

Meanwhile. While the British army was much smaller, they’d still have the powerful navy in the world and blockade the Russian-Persian port. And like they did in most colonies. They’d just pay a shit ton of Indians to be soldiers to defend India from Russia. Negating Russia’s population advantage

Would you agree with these points?

Also, was “the great game” even real? Or just British Political paranoia over the possibility of losing India, the biggest jewel in the berjtish empire

Russia didn’t seem to make much of an effort to conquer south beyond Kazakhstan and the very north of Persia.So I feel if they were actually invested in doing so, they could. Just not sure how they’’d manage it long them

It's very detailed, complex and elaborate answer Anon. One of the reasons is caste system, which is a very unique, interesting, complex phenomenon or element present exclusively in the Indic Hindu culture. Originally the castes were formed as a basis of hierarchy between various types of occupations performed by ancient Indians. Later on it shifted it's meaning from occupational based to birth or hereditary based element. And that is where things started going downhill. But in the very olden days, anybody could become a knowledgeable knower of Indian Hindu texts like Vedas regardless of his family, anybody could become warrior under a king to attain training and so was true for other occupations.
Another factor is that many separate Indian civilizations never believed in excessive violence, wars and bloodshed as well as expansion, unlike other civilizations (exceptions apply to Chola kingdom conquests and South Indian cultural influence in South East Asian countries and King Ashoka)
And many more.

1. Didn't have overwhelming national power
British Empire had a stronger navy than others, it did not have a strong army to conquer continental Europe. Because at that time, other Western European colonial empires were all in their heyday too, So, unlike the superpowers in history, So British Empire has never been in an overwhelming position.

This was demonstrated in WW I. They were obviously the world's largest empire, but in the end they couldn't defeat Germany, so the US took it down instead.

2. Most of the Empire's territory is uncivilized
Look at Mongol empire, Mongols conquered countries that had a strong influence until modern times, such as China, Persia, Russia, Arabs, and Central Asia, or countries that were the roots of ancient civilizations.

By comparison, what about the UK?

Africa, North America and Australia were literally tribal societies prior to the Stone Age. It's no exaggeration to say that it is truly empty. these lands are 70-80% of the territory. And so is India. The Mughal Empire was already divided before the arrival of the British. So the British were able to conquer India. This is why so many parts of India under British rule are self-governing and have only half of the British Empire's direct jurisdiction.

I mean, There is no doubt that they were the most powerful country that dominated the world's logistics and finance with their powerful navy. However, their national power was not overwhelming, and the territories of the empire they conquered were mostly divided lands and primitive tribal societies free from the rule of a central government.

>It's literally like a pirate. Pirate also don't have the power to conquer countries, but they do have the power to plunder coastal villages.

So I rate the British Empire lower than the Mongol Empire, the Roman Empire, and the Islamic Empire. But it's in the top 10. But it's hard to be in the top 5

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14433012
Humankind has enough productive capacity to provide every living human with basic food (rice and beans), potable water, commieblock apartment tier housing, and basic clothing. There is no need to prioritize.

>What about consumer goods, which goods need to be prioritized for production and who gets those goods as well?
You're used to the quote about "from each according to his ability, to each according to his need." Humans can create a surplus of goods beyond needs. Why would anyone contribute to society to his ability if his needs are met? This bring into the other socialist concept, "to each according to his contribution." Surplus goods can be distributed in some proportion to those who contribute to society the most. In effect, this is little different than how most wage-laborers see capitalism, if you work hard you will receive rewards. The difference to wage-labor is you don't have to work to survive, and there is no coercive means to force you to work just for sustenance. All work becomes a positive thing, with only positive rewards and motivation. The big difference is to the capital owning class. They no longer have rights to profit through ownership, nor will they control swaths of workers in order to generate private profit. Instead hard workers work towards the common good.

Adam Smith pointed out this often happens naturally due to the invisible hand in competitive market economies. He also mentioned rent seekers are assholes, capitalists abhor competition, and the capital owning class should not be entrusted with governance for a prosperous society.

Clearly the ideal near-future system is tax-regulated market socialism. This includes a very basic welfare state or state-sponsored part-time work-for-welfare. Behavior that is detrimental to society should be taxed in excess of the harm it causes. This ensures economic activity provides a net gain to society, and bad behavior is discouraged, rather than endorsed by property right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14433240
Privately owned capital should not extend past what one can personally make use of which prevents labor exploitation and excessive concentration of wealth and power. Spreading around capital makes it so more people can be entrepreneurs rather than trapped by lack of access to capital, and true entrepreneurship is the prime driver of economic growth. The state should steer the economy and discipline bad actors, but otherwise allow high degrees of freedom to maximize entrepreneurship. Large enterprises would be jointly owned, like a publicly traded company, except the board would answer to the workers and society as a whole instead of private shareholders. The government would also have increased powers to shut down economically antisocial and predatory behavior. You would have rights to basic needs, and the right to the means to be a productive member of society and enjoy the fruits of your labor, but you would not have inalienable rights to property, or to misuse property against your fellows and society. The core rights of such a society would be human and labor rights, not property rights. Rent seeking in general should be forbidden. A socialist society could separate R&D from production, eliminating the issue with big pharma by having the state fund drug research and issuing licenses to unaffiliated and competitive generic drug manufacturers. A competitive market economy could be much more effectively regulated to benefit society if it were not focused so much on property rights even when property rights lead to detrimental behavior and negative externalities.

There is Hitler's National Socialism which dives a bit into it. There is also The Nazi War Against Capitalism which is basically a short summary of other books showing their views on capitalism and a bit about the general economic ideas prevalent among the party. There were some who were more left wing and basically wanted to change the system of private property to one of private management. Meaning that you technically didn't own any factory or such but just managed it in service of the community. So if you went against those interests it would be taken away or you'd be placed more on the sidelines with a government manager coming in to keep an eye on it. Part of this was already implemented and it's likely Hitler subscribed somewhat to this idea. At the end of the war he became a bit more in favor of direct government control though so we can't be sure how it would be if a quick victory happened. All we know is that they'd move more against the old Conservative and capitalist groups since their cooperation for rearmament wouldn't be needed anymore. Also Otto Ohlendorf said in like 45 he thought of a system for a new National Socialist economy that could still respect private property but as far as I know it was not written down anywhere. Speer however said he found it really interesting.

Justice in civilized societies means settling interpersonal disputes, containing those too dangerous to roam free, and in some cases punishing those guilty of heinous crimes. Punishment through simple confinement or fines is meant to be a deterrent when applicable, to demonstrate that some behaviors aren't tolerated, and to preempt personal vengeance by the public. When punishment becomes deliberately cruel, arbitrary, or personal, the state starts to lose its status as a respectable, neutral third party that respects the rights of its citizens.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
People in this thread are misunderstanding what grieving or parenthood is like: sadness doesn't automatically translate into thirst for vengeance. What matters for the parent is the lost child, they want to focus on them and their memories of the time spent with them. Many will want to forget or ignore the cause of death to protect from the painful emotions linked to it, to push it away as a form of coping. Many are also empathetic to a point where they wish others didn't have to encounter a similar tragedy, rather than seeking for vengeance.

Situations where the government instutionalizes vengeance are unjust by design, given the state selects to use its divine rule to satiate a common bloodthirst towards misdeeds, ignoring not only the emotions of the victim but also the humanity of the criminal. Humane incarcenation is neither fully just, as we by nature are imperfect beings, but proves better results while seeking to better match the needs of every citizen involved. Hence, modern western society tends to incline towards it over more punituve forms of justice.

I believe in a mixed method like other anons have suggested.

One of my buddies is a prison guard and from what he told me and stuff I've read about US prisons, if you treat someone like an animal, they're going to be like an animal. I'm not going to "coddle" a rapist or murderer, but you have to give them some aspects of dignity. They get decent healthful meals, good toilet and sink in their cell, and Idle hands are the Devil's workshop so have them focus on learning academics or a trade, do stuff in the prison workshop (heavily monitored of course), physical fitness, and some entertainment time like movies or the library.

They don't get a cell that's like a youth hostel that Norway gets. And inmates should also spend time reflecting on what they did to be in prison and the impact of their poor decisions. Prison should focus on the 3 R's: Rehabilitation, Reform, and Retaliation. While you're in prison, you do not have voting rights. You are still a human being and accorded most of your civil rights, but you have to be out of prison to vote.

If they're a non-violent offender who did something stupid like steal a car or did illegal drugs, they should be drilled with discipline and the tools to be readmitted back into society and never to do shit like that again. So Rehabilitation in this case and they can get those nice rooms.

Repeat non-violent offenders need serious wake-up calls. So Reform. They get the nice room, but have limited free time. It's gonna be treated like boot camp. Wake up, fix your bed, make sure your prison uniform is nice and neat, do assigned tasks, go to school or learn how to do a trade. Exercise daily and maybe 1-2 hours of downtime. No TV or Internet. Magazines, newspapers, and books allowed.

Retaliation is violent offenders who show no remorse or being contrite. They have to do hard time. They will be paid an adequate wage (no slave labor that the prison industry loves to do) for doing jobs as well as manual labor.

>What the fuck was that about?
I went down a Sati rabbithole a while back. Turns out, its origins are steppe cultures. The rig veda briefly mentions it, and there are few recorded instances of Sati in literature for most of the Vedic period. In classical India you see individual examples in 8th century Nepal. After that, it was mostly known to exist in Rajput areas in Northwest India. There are a few Telugu/Tamil sources which mention it too, but only as a spectacle or rarity. In general it was unpopular among Hindu kings and later Mughal rulers. Both religions banned Sati multiple times, and the British also issued a ban. Weirdly, cases of Sati actually skyrocketed once the Brits began publicizing the practice.

>>14431219
First thing is that it's a tribal / sectarian conflict in American society which maps onto the political parties but isn't the same thing as them, but that's usually how people describe it because that's the only language they have to describe it.

The second thing is that while the U.S. system is structurally a two-party system which makes the parties seem strong, they're not really like political parties in Europe which can expel members or enforce some kinda discipline on them. For most parliamentary systems, there's an election and then the different parties create a coalition and then form a government. In the U.S. system, that coalition-building occurs within each "party" before the election. The party "conventions" are basically like marketing events for that coalition and the "platforms" are not binding, people who take the "platforms" seriously are chumps.

There's continuity within the parties between elections of course but if you go back 100 years you'd be looking at different political formations calling themselves "Democrats" and "Republicans." You see the rank-and-file GOP right now getting frustrated with this MAGA shit show, but are unable to cut them loose at this time, but when they do, that's when we'll see a new party form and it will compete to replace one of the main ones or collapse into irrelevance.

On the tribal conflict, if you ask me, I don't think most Republicans think they're "racist," but a lot of them believe in a white / Anglo-Saxon majority (and Christian) as being important because they're the core ethnic group of the country, which is important to maintain internal unity and stability. So things deemed to undermine that are opposed. Historically this was true and this core ethnic group is a thing, but I think nowadays the attempt to reinforce this ethnic group's core position (which the left calls supremacist or oppressive) is having the opposite effect of intensifying divisions in the country.

posts.com: Cause infantry combat usually boiled down to two lines of dudes with shields pushing against each other. Pilum were designed mainly to disable enemy shields before the clash, that's why they have long, flexible tips, so they'd bend after impacting and be hard to remove, so most likely the soldier drops the shield. Now you have a wimpy barbarian shield wall vs the big solid legionary shield wall. People near the front can try stabbing around the shields with their swords or other weapons, but this was mainly just to further weaken the shield wall and get it to collapse. If you could break through the enemy line and ruin their formation, they'd become confused, lose confidence, and maybe even make a run for it, leading to a full enemy rout. In premodern warfare most casualties were inflicted during routs, or prisoner executions after the battle, not the battle itself.

>The post-Neolithic demographic history of East-Central Europe, despite this region being on the confluence of various ecological zones and cultural entities is poorly explored. Particularly, the predominance of collective burials, the scale of which, was previously seen only in the Neolithic. To study kinship of those MBA societies and to test whether the re-emergence of those old traditions was a result of genetic shift or social changes, we generated and analyzed 91 genomes from individuals associated with EBA and MBA from modern day Poland and Ukraine. Our results indicate that while EBA people in East-Central Europe were most likely direct descendants of the preceding populations, the MBA populations were formed by an additional admixture event involving a population with relatively high proportions of genetic component associated with European hunter-gatherers. I wrote a big whole post but my window closed for some reason so I'll say
It depends on region, time period, and how much independence their local authority gave them.
If their lord didnt give them militias, they either would have to form a shoddy defense force or retreat to the castle. A militia could stand against a handful of bandits, but they could use stealth or an insider to get past them. A professional army force or trained raiders (vikings, magyars, etc) could easily overcome a small, unexperienced group of miltia, who'd rather grab their families and run.
If they were given walls, they get a lot better chance, but, like militia, it depends on how much their local lord wants to give autonomy, as those give easier ways to fight back against the lord. Walls would make raiders require quicker siege methods, stealth, or some way to infiltrate/get someone to open the gates.
For 7 samurai, they do hire ronin to create a decent militia to hold off a decent sized group of raiders, but at heavy cost to those 7 samurai and the peasantry.

From Pliny
>REMEDIES FOR DISEASES OF THE TONSILLARY GLANDS, AND FOR SCROFULA.
>Scrofulous sores are dispersed by applying the gall of a wild boar or of an ox, warmed for the purpose: but it is only when the sores are ulcerated that hare’s rennet is used, applied in a linen cloth with wine. The ashes of the burnt hoof of an ass or horse, applied with oil or water, is good for dispersing scrofulous sores; warmed urine also; the ashes of an ox’s hoof, taken in water; cow-dung, applied hot with vinegar; goat-suet with lime; goats’ dung, boiled in vinegar; or the testes of a fox. Soap, too, is very useful for this purpose, an invention of the Gauls for giving a reddish tint to the hair. >>14423055
There was trade with China via the Philippines. The galleon convoys from San Blas-Guam-Manila were the first regular transpacific commercial route in history, twice a year, bringing mostly spices, silk, textiles to New Spain. Trade was more unidirectional from Asia to America->Spain because there wasn't much the Philippines required from New Spain, and the Chinese weren't interested in anything at all except gold and silver, and nobody had a surplus trade balance with China, because they needed nothing from anyone until the english had them hooked on opium to collect chinese coins, and that was much later in the XIX century. In general, trade with Asia was deficitarian for European powers meaning you buy stuff from them with gold/silver but the buy little from you, unless you get direct access to those products by conquest, like the dutch in Indonesia and the English East India Company in India and sell them in the European markets, where the profit really is, or you economically exploit the local market/population to syphon away wealth, like the british in India. I guess that's what you mean by "entrepeneurship/businessman spirit".

In summary, you're talking shit.

Not sure what you mean. Spanish silver was the first world currency, accounting for the majority of the coin circulating in Europe, China and Japan for centuries. On top of that, the USA established their dollar on the real de a ocho, a Spanish coin, of which they gifted the Americans the right to print their currency on.
I recommend you read a book called The Silver Way: China, Spanish America and the Birth of Globalisation by Peter Gordon and Juan Jose Morales. You'll find out that, despite the propagated, rooted in the black legend, myth that Spain was economically incompetent, it was leagues ahead in both globalisation, innovation, and free trade compared to every other European kingdom. You can also read about the economists of the university of Salamanca and Alcala de Henares, who pioneered the acceptance of "usury" (just basic business loans) even before the modern period began.
>>14423264
This is true. During the Spanish empire, it was believed that it was preferrable to have crown control on as much trade as possible, since trade was considered fundamental to any war effort and therefore treated as a matter of "national security". However, while Spanish traders in Spanish dominions might have been worse off than English traders in English dominions, it helped in both strengthening connections with economic allies as well as maintaining a strong grip over its trade routs.
This would eventually change under the Bourbons, who allowed more autonomy in the viceroyalties, resulting in an infiltration of Spain's enemies in the Caribbean and Pacific, ensuring the eventual demise of the empire.

>It was precisely this absence of ‘people of the middling sort’, lamented by González de Cellorigo, which tended to differentiate the Spain of Philip III from other contemporary societies in western Europe (and conversely to approximate it to east European societies like Poland)...The uniqueness of Spain lay not so much in
this contrast, as in the absence of a middling group of solid, respectable, hardworking bourgeois to
bridge the gulf between the two extremes. In Spain, these people, as González de Cellorigo
appreciated, had committed the great betrayal. They had been enticed away by the false values of a disorientated society – a society of ‘the bewitched, living outside the natural order of things'.The contempt for commerce and manual labour, the lure of easy money from investment in censos and juros, the universal hunger for titles of nobility and social prestige - all these, when combined with the innumerable practical obstacles in the way of profitable economic enterprise, had persuaded the
bourgeoisie to abandon its unequal struggle, and throw in its lot with the unproductive upper class of society.
>The best guarantee of a regular supply of square meals was, by tradition, service in Iglesia, o mar, o casa real – Church, sea (trade), or the royal service (at Court or in the army). Castilians from all walks of life had come to look, as a matter of course, to the Church, Court, and bureaucracy to guarantee them the living which they disdained to earn from more menial occupations, at once despised and unrewarding.

>Younger sons and impoverished hidalgos flocked to the Court in the hope of making or restoring their fortunes – a hope that did not seem unreasonable when a Rodrigo Calderón could acquire the marquisate of Siete Iglesias and an annual income of 200,000 ducats. >Influence, favour, recommendation, were therefore essential passports. The more talented graduates had little hope of employment unless they could find an influential patron, and consequently a great army of students joined the ranks of the unemployed. Yet a degree conferred at least some status, and there was always the possibility of a lucky break...Everything, then, conspired to attract the population to the economically unproductive occupations in society. There was always the chance of a sudden piece of good fortune to end the long years of waiting; and anyhow, what alternative was there?...In fact, if Church, Court, and bureaucracy absorbed an excessive proportion of the potentially productive part of the population of Castile, this was not only because of their own innate attractiveness to a society which tended to despise the more menial occupations, but also because they offered almost the only prospect of remunerative employment in an underdeveloped economy.
A lot of this is still surprisingly applicable to modern-day Spain.

>>14428542
As someone else said, you're retarded and confusing logistics and mercantilism. Service workers aren't merchants, they're service laborers. Instead of providing a thing, they provide an action. Merchants peddle, they buy a thing and sell it somewhere else for higher so they can buy more things or more expensive things

Merchants aren't used for logistics. They do however become part of logistics. Nobody sells a produce to a merchant and tells them "cart that shit to the nearest town and bring me profits".

Here's 2 scenarios:

A) The producer just sells their produce to a merchant and now that merchant owns it. They can price it however they want to. They can go to the nearest town, sell it for stupid profit margin, come back and tell the producer "oh yeah don't sell anything in the town, they give you terrible prices. But I can take your produce out of your hands for a fair price!"

B) The producer hires someone who can cart the produce to the nearest town, sell it and bring back the profits. He has eliminated the middle-man in his business. He can either sell his produce at the same price as the merchant making stupid profits. But not everyone could afford it. Or he could sell his produce for cheaper so more people could afford it, bettering the lives of more people.

>The producer hires someone who can cart the produce to the nearest town, sell it and bring back the profits.
So he hires a merchant.

If there are dozens of suppliers and 10000s of buyers, buyers aren't going to spend all day driving around town visiting every supplier, neither are suppliers going to constantly knock on people's doors. There is no magic that instantly tells somewhere who will pay the most for their product, someone has to figure that out. That is literally the service provided by the merchant, and they often also handle freight as well.

>They can price it however they want to. They can go to the nearest town, sell it for stupid profit margin, come back and tell the producer "oh yeah don't sell anything in the town, they give you terrible prices.
The more merchants and the more competitive the market the less merchants are able to do this. When the state tries to control the market, this is usually what happens. The market gets less competitive, some corrupt official kicks out competitors and reaps massive profits. However in a free market, merchants quickly figure out the price is high in one town and they all rush there to sell, driving down prices.

Now let's imagine it is a competitive market, yet a merchant does his research and discovers there is still a price discrepancy. He has discovered untapped demand for a product that everyone else missed, or possibly he anticipated future demand. He knew that factories would need more aluminum, yet no one listened, so he bought aluminum himself and stockpiled it, then when the shortage came, he had plenty of aluminum to sell. Has a crime been committed here? He has literally made sure the factories can still get their aluminum, he has saved them a lot of trouble. Surely he is at least entitled to the money he made for his work researching the market.

You make some interesting points about looking at it from an ancient vs modern viewpoint.
However, I think that a big problem with a lot of Christian fundamentalists is they look at the bible and try to take it as literally as possible.
Going to far as to say the world was created in 6 days, there was a literal worldwide flood, and an actual Tower of Babel.
Even more liberal Christians justify following the Bible by saying it is supposed to contain wisdom from the divine creator of the universe.
But if you examine that wisdom it looks exactly like the kind of thing that a patriarch from a bronze age hill tribe would come up with.
Everything from the cosmology, to the morality, to the laws governing behavior are all what you would expect men of the time to write.
There is no "transcendent wisdom". Nothing beyond these human authors' understanding.
For instance, if there was a verse in Exodus that said, "Boil your water that it may be purified from the wee beasties that live in it and cause disease." then THAT would be transcendent wisdom.
But no, in the Old Testament it says to splash yourself with ox blood to purify yourself.
And in the New Testament it says to drink the (symbolic) blood of a demigod to purify yourself.
It is a collection of ancient superstition that we should have given up a long time ago.

I suppose there are some worthwhile moral values scattered throughout the book but you have to do some serious cherry picking to find them, and it is no different than any other holy book in that regard.
I think people like the "idea" of the Bible without actually every reading and understanding it.

The simpler and easier way to undercut them is to simply loosen the reins of zoning laws and construction permit gathering. Renting and companies that make fortunes off of rent are primarily profiting off of scarcities in housing markets, especially in hotspot cities where there are a lot of job growth and consequently people wanting to move in to take those jobs.

Though I would object to landlordery not on economic terms but social terms - the principle of accountability. A landlord does not care as much for their let property than their own property they are living in. And a rentoid doesn't care about the property they lease as much as they would their own. This leads to building neglect (damage), allows unconscientiousness (not caring), which I totally hate.

In terms of price, whether you banned landlords or not, in economic terms the net costs would realise themselves between purchase price / rent price either way. What is disallowed from one avenue will go into the other. No net difference when you add them up. But the costs of neglect from my point would be saved.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14432982
And, for that matter, all law has its origins in robbery and people trying to formalize extractive systems. Should we do away with all of that too?

The reason rent and landlords continue to exist is similar to the reason states exist; they're too useful to do away with, even by the people who are not primary beneficiaries of its apparatus. The ability to rent provides a huge degree of liquidity in an economy as you no longer need to have massive deposits and more massive ties to a location because purchase is the only option. Get rid of it, and you make everyone poorer. The landlords themselves will be worst hit, followed by the people who can't afford to buy and have to rent, followed by literally everyone as the increased cost of goods and services through lost opportunities filters its way back up.

Sure, you can go all woke moralist and say that you don't give a shit as long as you hurt the bad people, but some of us have actually grown up.

P.S. I don't have any idea why you'd think I'd find something persuasive just because Adam Smith said it. Try to back up your ideas with facts and logic, not FAMOUS GUY SAID SHIT.

The Miracle that Led Alec Guinness to Convert to Catholicism

"My son Matthew, then aged eleven, was stricken with polio and paralysed from the waist down. The future for Matthew looked doubtful, and in my anxiety I formed the habit of dropping in at a rather tawdry little Catholic church which lay on my route home. I didn't go to pray, to plead or to worship - just to sit quietly for ten minutes and gather what peace of spirit I could.

"After I had done this several times I struck a negative bargain with God. 'Let him recover', I said, 'and I will never put an obstacle in his way should he ever wish to become a Catholic.'

"It sounded to me like a supreme sacrifice on my part.

"About three months later he was able to walk in a stilted way. By Christmas he could play football. And not long afterwards I was taken up on the side of the bargain. We wanted to move out of London to the country, and we found only a Catholic school. The Rector explained to us: 'We only have three non-Catholic boys, and if he comes here I have no doubt that by the time he is sixteen he will wish to conform. They all do. No pressure will be put on him, I assure you, but it is most likely he will express the wish to be received. Would you object?'

"I hesitated, and then said, 'No.'

"Matthew went to Beaumont and at the age of fifteen announced that he was going to submit himself to the Holy Roman Catholic and Apostolic Church.

"I later went to spend some days in a Trappist monastery. The life at the Abbey impressed me deeply. If this was the worst that Rome had to offer, it was pretty good. On March 24, 1956, Fr Clarke accepted my reconciliation with the Church, with tact and kindness. Like countless converts before and after me, I felt I had come home."

From these pre-Incaic elements, the image could represent the ancient temple of Pachacamac, built in honor of the local god of the place, popular in much of the northern part of the Inca Empire, although the perspective seems more in line with the much larger and more recent Temple of the Sun built by the Incas.
The local non-Inca temple at Pachacamac was occupied by the Wari (among others), but when the Incas conquered the sactuary it was an Ichma temple and was painted with distinctive Ichma motifs (very diferent from Wari's), so it is also called the Painted Temple. In this temple survived a representation of the god Pachacamac, a wooden pole dating to the Wari period. As I said the Chavin were much older and all their sanctuaries and style had already been abandoned long ago, none surviving into the time of the Incas, not to mention that Chavin stone stelae are extremely rare and the few found are in the heart of Chavin, in its temple and nearby vicinity, not a single one has been found on the coast or so far away.

>>14432567
Knitting didn't exist in the pre-Columbian Andes, although they knew practically all other weaving techniques known today.

Similarly, ponchos appear to have been rare in comparison to today. Although they appear in some pre-Inca cultures (especially coastal ones) such as Paracas, for the most part they did not have the proportions of today's ponchos, the common attire of most highland provinces during the Inca empire was an uncu, which is a sleeveless tunic with a yacolla or blanket around it, which was still the common attire recorded in many parts in early colonial times, the rise in popularity of today's ponchos is rather hazy, but seems to have been an evolution of uncus from which the sides were left unstitched.

>>14429625
>>The Matrix scenario can be disproved by Occam's razor.
Very much so, albeit not exactly "disproved" in an absolute sense. Occam's razor's 21st century variant is called Solomonoff induction. It means the bayesian prior probability we give a hypothesis should decrease exponentially with the length of the computer code that would generate that hypothesis. So in this example, living in "a physics matrix reconstruction of an event that somehow happened ages ago" is a priori less likely than just living in "a physics matrix that never turns off" which is indistinguishable from naturalism.

>you proven the existance of the phaneron, not reality.
Reality is the law by which all phanerons evolve in time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Richard Speck was one of three mass murderers to hit the United States during the summer of 1966, along with Charles Whitman, who shot more than a dozen persons at the University of Texas, and Robert Benjamin Smith, who shot four women in a Mesa, Arizona beautician's school.

Speck was born in the little village of Kirkwood in central Illinois in 1941, the day before Pearl Harbor. Soon after his birth, his parents, Benjamin and Mary, moved to Monmouth along with his six siblings--Richard's four sisters and two brothers were quite a bit older than him, and the firstborn child, Robert, was 12 years his senior (Robert died in a car accident when Richard was 11). The Specks had one more child, Carolyn, born in 1943. Benjamin Speck was a typical working class Midwesterner, having farmed and worked in logging, and now employed at a factory that manufactured cookware. Richard was close to his father, but Benjamin passed away from a heart attack when the boy was only six.

In 1950, three years after Benjamin's death, Mary met a new love interest; a traveling salesman from Texas named Carl Lindberg. Lindberg was a grizzled man with a missing leg, a drinking habit, and a criminal history. Although Mary was a quiet, religious non-drinker, she became smitten with him. The two traveled down to Texas to tie the knot in May. Richard and Carolyn stayed with their older, married sister Sarah in Monmouth while their mother was away.
posts.filename: richard speck conversing with his public defender 11-4-66

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
After a few months, the children went to live with their mother and new stepfather in Santo, Texas. However, Richard did not get along with Carl, who drank heavily, was frequently AWOL, and constantly insulted and threatened him. Mary also began drinking, her new husband having softened her previous resistance to alcohol. The family moved around constantly, always in lower class neighborhoods, and Richard struggled with school. He was diagnosed with myopia but resisted wearing eyeglasses. Richard flunked the 8th grade and had to repeat it. He performed very poorly in 9th grade and dropped out of school in January 1958, a few weeks after his 16th birthday. Richard had also started drinking alcohol when he was 12, and by 15 he was a heavy drinker. Starting with an arrest for trespassing when he was 13, he accumulated dozens of other arrests over the next eight years.

Speck worked at a bottling plant in Dallas for three years. In the fall of 1961, he met 15 year old Shirley Malone at the state fair and started dating her. She became pregnant within a few weeks, and the two got married in January 1962. Shirley moved in with Richard and his mother; Carolyn was also married now, and her husband shared the family home with them. Carl Lindberg was long gone; he'd separated from Mary and moved to California. Richard decided to start calling himself Richard Speck instead of Richard Lindberg.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When Shirley gave birth to a daughter, Robbie Lynn, on July 5, Richard was not around as he was sitting in the county jail for drunk and disorderly conduct. A year later, he was charged with forgery after writing a co-worker's name on a paycheck and cashing it, and shoplifting from a grocery store. He received three years in prison but only served 16 months of his sentence. On January 9, 1965, one week after getting out of jail, Speck lunged at a woman in the parking lot of an apartment complex with a carving knife. She screamed and ran; police arrived, and Richard fled the scene. He was found hiding a few blocks away and charged with aggravated assault in addition to violating the terms of his parole.

Speck was sent back to prison to serve another 16 months for the assault charge, running concurrently with six months for parole violation. However, a mix-up in paperwork led to his being released on July 2, after having only completed the six month part of his sentence. He got a job as a truck driver for a meatpacking plant, but got into repeated accidents with the company trucks and was finally fired after failing to show up for work. Shirley had left Richard during his jail sentence and taken their daughter with her. His mother hooked him up with a new love interest, a 29 year old divorced mother, bartender at his favorite watering hole Ginny's Lounge, and part-time female wrestler who needed a babysitter for her three children.

Shirley formally divorced her husband in January 1966. In the divorce papers, she cited repeated physical and psychological abuse to herself and her mother by Speck. She was also unable to keep up with his voracious sexual demands and claimed he had once raped her at knifepoint.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Shortly after that, Speck stabbed a bar patron at Ginny's Lounge in a drunken argument and was arrested for aggravated assault but Mary hired an attorney for her son who succeeded in getting the charge reduced to disorderly conduct. He spent three days in jail and paid a $10 fine. On March 5, Speck bought a 1954 Oldsmobile at a used car lot. He broke into a grocery store, stole 70 cartons of cigarettes, sold them out of the trunk of his car, and then abandoned it. Police ran a license plate check on the Oldsmobile, found it was registered to Speck, and put out an arrest warrant.

On March 9, Carolyn decided to help her brother escape from the law by driving him to a bus station in Dallas where he caught the bus to Chicago. He spent a few days with his sister Martha there, and then went back to his childhood home in Monmouth where he stayed with some old family friends. His brother Howard, a carpenter, arranged for him to get a job with a contractor he knew. During this time, Richard learned that Shirley had gotten remarried just two days after filing for divorce from him, and he was not happy about it. He spent much of his time in local bars getting sloshed, and spent a night in jail in Monmouth after threatening a bar patron with a knife. It was now that Richard Speck was about to cross the line from a drunkard and petty criminal to a sadistic killer.

On April 3, a 65 year old Monmouth woman named Virginia Harris entered her home to find Speck inside holding a knife. He tied her up, raped her, and burglarized the house. She called police and said her attacker was a tall white man, over 6' in height, who was quiet and soft-spoken, with a noticeable Southern accent. On April 9, Mary Pierce, a 32 year old barmaid, disappeared while leaving work. Her body was found in a hog shed behind the tavern four days later. An autopsy found that Mary had died of internal bleeding from a very hard blow to the abdomen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Because Speck was known to frequent the tavern Mary worked in, and he had helped build the hog shed, he was briefly questioned by police. When police showed up at the Christy Hotel on April 19 to continue their questioning of Speck, they found that he had left the hotel a few hours earlier carrying his suitcases and saying he was just going to the laundromat, but had instead left town. A search of his room turned up a radio and costume jewelry that Mrs. Harris had reported missing from her house as well as items reported missing in two other local burglaries in the past month.

On April 19, Speck went back to his sister Martha's place where she lived with her husband and two teenage daughters, and told them a fanciful tale that some mobsters had tried to talk him into selling drugs, but he refused and now he had to leave Monmouth for fear that they might come back and get him. Martha's husband Gene, a Navy veteran, suggested Richard could get a job with the US Merchant Marine. He took Speck to the Coast Guard recruiting office on April 25 to help him enlist.

He was quickly accepted and assigned to the freighter Clarence B. Randall, which operated on the Great Lakes. But only four days into his new job as a merchant seaman, Speck fell ill with appendicitis and had to be airlifted to a hospital in Chicago where he had his appendix removed. He returned to duty on May 20, but four weeks later got into a drunken fight with an officer and was put ashore. He stayed in a flophouse on the East Side of Chicago for a week, and then went to Houghton, Michigan to visit Judy Laakaniemi, a 28 year old nurse's aid he'd met in Chicago. She loaned him $80 and on June 27, he was back with his sister and her family.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
On June 30, his brother-in-law Gene drove Speck to the National Maritime Union (NMU) hiring hall at 2335 E. 100th St. in the Jeffery Manor neighborhood of South Deering to file his paperwork for a seaman’s card. The NMU hiring hall was a block east of six attached two-story brick townhouses, three of which were occupied by South Chicago Community Hospital senior student nurses and Filipino exchange registered nurses, eight of whom lived in the easternmost townhouse at 2319 E. 100th St., just 150 feet from the NMU hiring hall.

On July 8, Richard tried to get a berth on the freighter SS Flying Spray, which was to travel from San Francisco to South Vietnam but a more experienced sailor beat him to it. He went back to his sister's apartment, but by this point his in-laws were starting to get annoyed with him. Gene once again drove Richard down to the NMU hiring hall, and he stayed in a boarding house in Vets Park. He tried to apply for a berth on a Great Lakes tanker ship, but once again didn't get the job. Since Richard was out of money for a room in a boarding house, he simply slept in an unfinished house off East 103rd St.

Martha visited Richard on July 13 and loaned him $25 which he used to pay for board at the Shipyard Inn on the East Side. After spending a day drinking in several bars, he picked up a 53 year old woman named Ella Hooper, raped her, and stole her .22 Rohm revolver. He went to a restaurant for dinner, returned to the bar where he met Ella for more drinks, and headed to the nurses' townhouse at 2319 E. 100th St.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Toting only a knife, Speck broke into the townhouse, which was functioning as a dormitory for several student nurses, he raped and murdered Gloria Davy, Patricia Matusek, Nina Schmale, Pamela Wilkening, Suzanne Farris, Mary Ann Jordan, Merlita Gargullo, and Valentina Pasion. Speck would claim he was drunk and high on drugs; his intent may have only been a burglary that got completely out of hand. He held the nurses captive for hours, raping, stabbing, and strangling them. One nurse, Corazon Amurao, survived by hiding under a bed. After she was sure that Speck was gone, she went out to the balcony and screamed for help. CPD officers arrived to process the gruesome crime scene.

CPD homicide division chief Frank Flannagan instructed Joe Cummings, police reporter for WCFL, to not write anything in his press release except that the victims' throats were cut. When Cummings asked why, Flannagan told him "Because we're gonna get every kook in the city saying he killed these girls. Leave the particulars out; only the killer will know what really happened to those girls."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dectective Jack Wallenda was the first homicide detective to view the scene; even a hardened cop like him had a hard time dealing with the gruesome scene before him. Gloria Davy lay nude and bound with strips of bedsheet. Droplets of semen could be seen on her buttocks. A large white T-shirt lay nearby. Pamela Wilkening was gagged and stabbed in the chest. Suzanne Farris had been stabbed 18 times, bound, and a stocking tied around her neck. Mary Ann Jordan had been stabbed in the chest, face, and left eye. Nina Schmale had her nightgown pulled up to her breasts, bound with strips of bedsheet, and strangled. Small lacerations were present around her neck. Valentina Paison lay under a bedsheet, her throat cut. Thrown over top her body was Merlita Gargullo, body face-up, stabbed and strangled. In the next room lay Patricia Matusek, bound, strangled, her panties pulled down around her legs, and her nightie rolled up to her breasts. She had a bruise mark to her stomach, suggesting she'd been kicked. The bathroom floor had a pile of bloodied towels on it.

It seemed very likely that the killer lived around here and knew the area because the nurses' residence was not an easily visible structure and one had to already know it was there. Corazon Amurao, the only living witness besides the killer himself, said it was a tall blonde man with a Southern accent. The numerous bars and flophouses in this part of Chicago were host to a variety of shady characters. Sgt. Ed Wielosinski found at the Union Hall that a blonde seaman had missed out on a double assignment and was not happy about it. This seaman was apparently not native to the Chicago area as he had a thick Southern accent, in fact he had a hard time understanding his speech. The assignment sheet read "Richard B. Speck."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Confident he wouldn't be caught, Speck hit up the local bars during the days after the murders and ended up staying in the Starr Hotel, a filthy dive that charged a mere 85 cents a night for a room. The rooms had no windows, cement floors, and only cots and a foot locker for furnishings. It was home to transients, vagrants, petty criminals, and other human refuse. The smell of cheap alcohol, excrement, puke, and the sound of drunken men vomiting and carrying on filled the noxious air.

Two days after the murderers, a drifter named Claude Lunsford saw Speck outside the Starr Hotel, recognized him from a sketch of the murderer provided by Ms. Amurao's description, and called police but no action was taken. Speck then attempted suicide in the hotel lobby by overdosing on pills, but staff called an ambulance. He was taken to the hospital and treated. But an assistant physician recognized him from the wanted poster and called police again. This time he was taken into custody, but uncertainty in the aftermath of Miranda v. Arizona meant that Speck sat in jail three weeks before police interviewed him.

When Speck was taken into custody, he had a nasty laceration on one arm from accidentally cutting himself with a broken wine bottle. He was taken to a hospital to get the wound sutured; making sure he stayed healthy and alive was important for the prosecution of the case.

A panel of psychiatrists interviewed Speck to assess his sanity. They found him a troubled and emotionally complex individual who however loved his family. He seemed to idolize women until they betrayed him or did him wrong and then came to detest them. They believed Speck had cognitive impairment due to past head trauma, was sane, but not sane at the time he did the killings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
His trial in Cook County Superior Court began April 3, 1967. Corazon Amurao took the witness stand and said that Speck was unquestioningly the man who assaulted and killed her colleagues. She recalled that Speck knocked on the door of the nurses' residence the evening of July 14. He had a gun pointed at her and asked where her colleagues were. Pushing past Cora, he walked inside. By that time, Merlita had gotten out of bed. Speck walked both women down the hall to the large bedroom in the back. Flicking on the light, he saw three women sleeping. Cora, Merlita, and Valentina hid in a closet, frightened. Then, when one of the women knocked on the closet door and assured her roommates the man would not harm them, they came out.

Speck pointed the gun at Nina and Pat, while holding Pamela around the waist. He switched off the light and made the women sit in a semi-circle, their backs to the window. Speck sat facing them smiling, his long legs and slow Texas drawl made him seem like a buddy, someone close to their age. "I want some money. I'm going to New Orleans." Each asked permission to get their purses and gave Speck all their money. After a while, Gloria Davy came home from a date with her boyfriend. She staggered up the stairs half drunk and opened the door to the bedroom. She screamed a low guttural scream when she saw Speck with a gun. Gloria joined the circle. Speck got up, tore a sheet from one of the bunk beds and began cutting them up into strips. One by one, he tied each woman's hands and feet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Two other nurses, Mary Ann and Suzanne, back from a chat session, opened the door to the back bedroom and found Speck hovering over a bound and gagged Pamela, her eyes filled with terror. They bolted down the hall right into the big room and screamed when they saw all the others tied up. Speck, in hot pursuit behind them, pushed them into another bedroom. He stabbed and strangled the two women as they fought back. Then he washed up and returned to Pamela to finish her off with one stab to her heart. He washed again. In the bedroom, the girls tried to squeeze themselves under the narrow bunk beds. Speck untied Nina's feet, led her down the hall to a bedroom, stabbed her in her neck and suffocated her with a pillow. Cora heard her gasping and gurgling. Cora struggled even more to get her head under the bunk.

Speck appeared and took Valentina, not bothering to untie her feet. He easily lifted the 100 pound woman and carried her to her death. Cora again heard gurgling sounds. He returned for Merlita, lifting her and carrying her off. Five minutes passed. Cora heard her exclaim "Masakit!" (Tagalog for "It hurts.") Another 30 minutes passed and the water sounds. Before he took Pat Matusek, an athletic 155 pound woman, Cora heard him ask, "Are you the girl in the yellow dress?" He led Pat to the bathroom, punched her in the stomach, rupturing her hepatic artery, and strangled her.

Speck came back to the room, disrobed Gloria, who was passed out drunk, and raped her. As the bedsprings squeaked and groaned, Cora watched, then closed her eyes and prayed. When she opened them again, they were gone. Cora decided to switch beds, she rolled and scooted her way across the bedroom floor, knowing that any moment Speck could come in and drag her to her death. She made it under the bed and wedged herself in as tight against the wall as possible, and waited.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Cora's testimony made the events of that night come alive for everyone in the courtroom. Speck's comment about the yellow dress clearly indicated that Speck had seen the girls before the murders. He planned the killing spree. Getty tried to dispute the fingerprints by calling in expert witness, but it backfired. The prosecution made a great case.

Fingerprints found at the crime scene matched Speck's prints, which had been taken as part of his application for the merchant marine. A jury took just 49 minutes to find him guilty. They recommended the death penalty and Judge Herbert Paschen sentenced him to death. The Illinois state supreme court upheld the sentence in November 1968.

In July 1971, the Supreme Court voided Speck's death sentence on procedural errors because more than 250 potential jurors were unconstitutionally excluded from his jury because of their conscientious or religious scruples against capital punishment. The case was remanded back to the Illinois Supreme Court for re-sentencing. Furman v. Georgia a year later made the issue moot; Speck would merely serve life in prison.

Speck remained incarcerated in the state prison in Stateville. He was quiet and largely kept to himself, collecting stamps and listening to music as his main hobbies; prison staff found him a pretty boring guy, although he got into frequent trouble for smuggling drugs within the prison or possessing pruno (a homemade alcoholic drink inmates make by fermenting fruit, vegetables, and anything else they can obtain that has sugar in it). Speck would often exclaim "I'm here for 1,200 years. What more can they do to me?"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Normally unwilling to speak to the media, he consented to one interview in 1978 with Bob Greene of the Chicago Tribune. He hoped to be paroled sometime soon and he didn't consider himself a "celebrity" killer like Dillinger or Lee Harvey Oswald. "Oh no, I'm not like Dillinger. I'm a lot more freakish." He admitted he had been like a robot on the night he killed the nurses and felt nothing at all while doing it, but he regretted it now and wished he hadn't done it.

In 1996, Chicago TV anchor Bill Kurtis got VHS tapes from anonymous sources that had been shot at Stateville Prison eight years earlier. The tapes were shown to an appalled state legislature; they contained explicit footage of inmates using drugs, passing money around, and engaging in sex acts. In the middle of it all was Richard Speck, who was snorting cocaine with one inmate, performing oral sex on another one, walking around in women's underwear, and sporting fake breasts he grew with smuggled hormonal treatments as he exclaimed "If they knew how much fun I was having, they'd let me out." The state legislature watched the graphic two hour video but called it quits at the scene of Speck blowing another man.

From behind the camera, another inmate asked Speck why he killed the nurses. He shrugged and said "It wasn't their night. If you wonder whether I feel guilty or not, the answer is no. I really just felt nothing." He added "Strangling someone isn't as easy as the movies make it look. It took a good three minutes and it requires a lot of strength." John Schmale, the brother of one of the victims, said he was appalled at how Speck could so nonchalantly talk about killing his sister.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Parts of the tapes were later broadcast on the A&E Network's Investigative Reports. The same airing of Investigative Reports included interviews with people who believed that Speck was not taking hormones, wearing panties, or performing sex acts on fellow inmates voluntarily, and that he'd instead been forced to--this may have been his way of surviving his time in prison.

By the time the tapes were revealed to the public, however, Richard Speck was long dead. He passed away of a heart attack on December 5, 1991, one day short of his 50th birthday, in Silver Cross Hospital in Joliet, which he was taken to after complaining of chest pain. An autopsy revealed an enlarged heart and severely occluded coronary arteries. His brain was examined and pathologists found that the hippocampus and amygdala were malformed and overlapped each other. The pathologists planned to send samples of brain tissue to a Boston neurologist for examination, but they went missing en route and never reached him. However Dr. John Hughes said that Speck's brain was extremely unusual and he had never seen a deformity of that nature. He attributed Speck's violent tendencies on this, his abusive upbringing at the hands of his stepfather, and a history of heavy drinking.

Nobody was willing to claim Speck's body, and his sister Martha said burying him in a local cemetery would be a terrible idea and a magnet for vandals. She had told her daughters they had to keep it a family secret that Richard Speck was their uncle. Instead he was cremated and his ashes scattered in a private ceremony.

>The Specks were an extremely pious family and the fear of divine punishment used to keep the children in line. Mary Speck was more overtly religious than her husband Ben, but he was also a man of deep faith. By the time Richard came into the world one December afternoon in 1941, it had been a while since the Specks welcomed a new baby. Richard's siblings ranged from six to twelve years older than him and he was relatively isolated until his sister Carolyn came along two years later. The two were childhood playmates and close companions growing up in the crowded Speck home. The eldest two Speck children, Sarah and Robert, had left home by the time Richard was in the 3rd grade. Perhaps as a reaction to losing them, Mary tried to keep Richard and Carolyn her babies as long as possible.

>Richard was only six when he lost his father. Ben had a heart attack at work and died en route to the hospital. The boy was devastated and while Mary and his older sisters quickly moved on, Richard continued to grieve over Ben. Mary's decision to hook up with Carl Lindberg in 1950 made it worse. Lindberg was the total opposite of Ben; a smooth-talking, hard-drinking, cigar-smoking insurance salesman and Mary completely fell for him. While Carolyn quickly accepted him as her new father, Richard never did. Carl just as quickly wrote off Richard. Being forced to take Carl's surname and move to Texas with him was more than he could take.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>The Santo home that Carl had moved the family into was squalid and reeked of tobacco smoke in every room. Empty liquor bottles lay everywhere. Although Carl had a higher income than Ben had had, he squandered most of his money and the family had worse living conditions than before. Mary also gradually discovered her new husband's rap sheet, several arrests for drunk driving and forgery.

>Despite his obvious alcoholism and sleazy lifestyle, Carl was affectionate to Mary and Carolyn. But the dislike between him and Richard was palpable. One day their resentment got physical when Richard took a hammer and swung it at Carl. But the 10 year old boy was no match for a grown man and Carl easily subdued him, ridiculing him all the way. Instead, he grabbed the hammer and smashed it into Richard's head, knocking the boy unconscious. By now Carl was afraid; if word got out he'd lose his new family for sure. Carl had a missing leg and had been exempted from WWII service as a result; he had never seen a dead body and wouldn't know what to do. After a few tense minutes, Richard regained consciousness and Carl berated him. However, Carl had no idea that he'd inflicted a brain injury that would affect Richard for the rest of his life.

His rap sheet started at 13 and grew longer and longer as his school attendance grew more sporadic.

>As Richard entered into adolescence, he began to notice girls but was always too shy to talk to them. No doubt he was also terribly insecure over his family's lifestyle and his own physical appearance; poor living conditions, alcohol and pill use, and luck of genetics resulted in a face that was permanently scarred with acne. >As Carolyn entered high school, she had become an attractive, outgoing, and confident girl who made friends easily, and also love interests. Richard remained extremely close to his sister and never harmed or raised his voice to her but he had a lot of built-up anger towards his mother, and she sometimes became the victim of his violent outbursts when he drank too much. Mary sported frequent black eyes and at least once Richard broke her jawbone from a hard punch. But she took his abuse without complaint, perhaps feeling she deserved it. Carolyn got married in her senior year of high school and moved her husband into the family home. He accepted his new brother-in-law as a bit of oddball but basically harmless.

>Richard did not have many pastimes outside drinking, but he did enjoy the Texas State Fair which set up shop in Dallas every October; in the Southern US, it is customary to have outdoor fairs and carnivals in the fall rather than the unbearable heat and humidity of summertime. It was here that Richard set his eyes on 15 year old Shirley Malone, who was attending the fair with her parents. A pretty girl, blonde, and just starting to look like a woman, Shirley resembled Carolyn and Richard became smitten with her. Shirley's parents let her go off with Richard by herself around the fairgrounds and when it was time to go home, the two promised to see each other again. Shirley lived in Dallas, though in a more middle class section of town.

>In Monmouth lived Richard's brother Howard, who had made a living as a carpenter and now owned his own contracting outfit--Howard was one of the main sources of income their mother relied on and he offered to give his wastrel little brother a shot. Although Richard took to carpentry work well, he spent nearly all the money he made on booze. Unlike the domineering Gene Thornton, Howard was not one to make an issue out of Richard's personal habits but he did always dread when he'd stumble home in the early hours of the morning sloshed. He was relieved when Richard announced he was moving out, to the Christy Hotel. Although it was the cheapest hotel in Monmouth, it was still more expensive than living at Howard's place for free. Also Richard had numerous acquaintances, some of them grade school classmates who hadn't seen him in over 15 years, but mostly co-workers, who were helping drain his bank account by encouraging him to drinking challenges.

>On the last weekend of March 1966, Richard and his buddies went on a drinking tour in Gulf Point. In a restroom there, someone made an off-color joke that Richard didn't find very funny. He slammed the man's head into the wall and pulled a knife on him. His buddies separated the two, but the man was incensed enough to call police, and Richard was charged with assault and spent a night in jail. He was at risk of losing his contracting job, and he had tense relations with co-workers.

>Life on the Clarence B. Randall was difficult for Richard to adjust to--he wasn't used to having his every move ordered, even prison wasn't this strict. But perhaps some rules and a sense of structure were exactly what he needed to turn himself around. Unfortunately, on May 3, only four days into his sojourn on the freighter, he fell violently ill. Richard failed to report for duty that morning, so the captain sent some crewmen down to living quarters to see what the problem was. They found him laying there on the bunk curled up in obvious pain, flush, and sweating profusely. Although there was no on-ship doctor, the sailors knew Richard was in trouble and needed medical attention. A helicopter was called to airlift him from the Clarence B. Randall to a hospital in Hancock, Michigan where he underwent an emergency appendicectomy.

>Richard became entranced by the pretty young nurses everywhere, and his eye fell on 28 year old Judy Laakaniemi, a nurse's assistant who had lately divorced her husband. The two became close and would sit and talk for hours in the hospital room. He was depressed to lose her companionship when he was discharged two weeks later.

>Gene obliged and drove him into Indiana with a touch of arrogance at Richard's dependence on him. While he sat waiting, Richard came back red-faced and enraged. He'd missed yet another ship's berth. Gene shrugged and told him he couldn't always be his personal chauffeur like this. He dropped him off by the roadside and left. Richard had no money at all and no place to go. He found a construction site nearby and laid down and went to sleep inside a partially finished house.

posts.com:
Christina Riggs became the first female executed by Arkansas in the modern era for the asphyxiation murder of her two small children in 1997. It was the culmination of a train wreck of a life that began with her birth as Christina Thomas in Lawton, Oklahoma in 1971. Her stepbrother molested her from the ages of 7 to 13 and then a neighbor did likewise. By 14, she was drinking alcohol, smoking cigarettes, and using marijuana. Struggling with obesity issues, Christina became sexually promiscuous since she thought otherwise she couldn't interest boys due to her weight. She became pregnant at 16, allegedly by an African-American boyfriend, gave birth to a son in January 1988, and immediately gave him up for adoption.

Graduating high school in 1989, she became a licensed practical nurse, doing part-time home visits and also working at the VA Hospital in Oklahoma City. Christina had several boyfriends during this time, including a bar bouncer, a Navy serviceman named Jon Riggs, and an Air Force serviceman named Tim Thompson, who was stationed at Tinker Air Force Base. In October 1991, Christina discovered that she was pregnant and enthusiastically told Tim the news. But he doubted the child was actually his and went back to his native Minnesota.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Shortly after this, she got together with Jon Riggs who was happy to accept the baby and raise it as his own. She gave birth to her son Justin on June 7, 1992. Jon Riggs moved in with Christina and she became pregnant again in early 1993. The two got married in July, but she had a miscarriage on their wedding night. This and her unhappy marriage made her increasingly depressed and suicidal; she started using Prozac. It wasn't long before she became pregnant for the fourth time; her daughter Shelby Alexis arrived in December 1994. Christina claimed to have worked a triage station near the blast site of the Oklahoma City Bombing in April 1995 where she suffered PTSD from viewing the mutilated victims of the bombing, but her work records from the VA Hospital have no indication of her doing this assignment.

That summer, her and Jon decided to move to Sherwood, Arkansas to be closer to her mother Carol. She went to work at Baptist Hospital where Carol worked in food service. Justin and Shelby also suffered from a myriad of childhood health issues including chronic ear infections and attention deficit disorder, making them a handful to deal with. Shortly after that, Jon punched Justin in the stomach so hard that he required hospitalization. Christina filed for divorce, having little money to support them with.

Christina was supposed to receive child support payments from Jon but they came only irregularly and she also had to shell out considerable money on daycare services for Justin and Shelby while she was working at the Arkansas Heart Hospital. She claimed she was struggling to pay her bills and was considering suicide.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The end came on November 4, 1997 when she collected a deadly cocktail of drugs--her prescription antidepressants, morphine, and potassium chloride from the hospital where she worked. She gave Justin and Shelby a small dosage of Elavil to get them asleep. Potassium chloride, as some may know, is used to execute death row inmates via lethal injection. Normally it is administered diluted or it will cause a painful burning sensation. Christina injected Justin with it, but hadn't bothered diluting the stuff first. The 5 year old boy woke up and started yelping in pain. Next she tried giving him morphine without success, so she decided to simply smother him with a pillow. She went to Shelby's room and having decided now that potassium chloride was a bad idea, just smothered her. Christina placed both bodies next to each other and covered them with a blanket.

Then she penned suicide notes to her mother and ex-husband, consumed 28 Elavil tablets, and injected herself with a large dose of undiluted potassium chloride, which burned a hole the size of a quarter in her right arm. The next day when she didn't show up at the hospital for work, her mother decided to call her house. There was no answer so she drove there herself, stepped inside, and discovered the horror within. Her two grandchildren lay dead on the floor. Nearby was an unconscious Christina, whom Carol assumed to be dead too. "I walked in there, saw the bodies, and started panicking and yelling 'No, no, no!' I called 911 and yelled 'My god, my daughter and her babies are dead!'"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Police and paramedics found that Christina was alive, but barely. Taken to the Baptist Memorial Medical Center in North Little Rock, her condition was stabilized and then moved to intensive care after police found the syringes and suicide notes in the house. As soon as she was released from the hospital, she was arrested for first degree murder. Tried in Pulaski County Superior Court in June 1998, she pled innocent by reason of insanity. Her defense said she had a lifelong history of depression and serious weight issues; she was currently over 280 pounds. It was obvious that she had attempted a murder-suicide and was seriously mentally ill.

The defense mentioned that Christina's family had a history of depression and mental disorders, that she had been sexually abused as a child, and she was in major financial trouble after her divorce, unable to pay her bills. The prosecution however depicted her in more callous terms. They disputed the claims of Christina's abysmal financial situation, noting that she was making good money as a full-time nurse with a $17,000 a year income ($31,000 in 2020 dollars, plus Arkansas was one of the cheapest states to live in) and that Jon Riggs had been reliably sending child support payments. They also claimed Christina often spent Saturday nights off in karaoke bars leaving the kids home alone or with her mother. The prosecution's conclusion was that they'd become an inconvenience to Christina and she wanted to be rid of them. Furthermore, they believed she didn't really intend to kill herself, just the children, and it was a fake suicide attempt for attention.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The truth may not be known. Had Christina succeeded in offing herself, she would have just warranted a brief headline in the local news as another tragic case of a mother who killed her children and herself. In any case, she was sentenced to death on June 30. Governor Mike Huckabee declined to grant her clemency and she was executed via lethal injection on May 2, 2000, the only female on Arkansas's death row and only the fourth executed in the United States since 1976. Christina showed no particular inclination to appeal her sentence and said she was at peace with herself and wanted to be reunited with her children in the next world. She admitted the prison food was enjoyable and she liked eating it, exacerbating her existing obesity issues; she claimed to have gained an additional 30 pounds since going to prison.

Executions of women are relatively uncommon and controversial when they do happen. In fact (if one excludes lynched African-American women) there had only been one other legal execution of a female in Arkansas history, that of Lavinia Burnett all the way back in 1845 after she had carried out a Bonnie and Clyde-style heist with her husband Crawford--the two conspired to rob and murder a wealthy man in Fayetteville. What's more surprising is that the Burnetts were an older couple in their late 50s with two adult children, hardly reckless punk kids like Bonnie and Clyde. The pair were hanged on November 8; their son John followed them to the scaffold December 28 as an accomplice to murder after having fled across the state line to Missouri, where he was captured.

But that was back when executions were carried out at the county level. The state of Arkansas took over capital punishment in 1913, replacing hangings with the electric chair. During the 87 years between this and Christina Riggs's execution, four women had been sentenced to death in Arkansas but all had their sentences commuted to life in prison.
